message_1: What is the standard potential of a cell in which an electrode made of nickel (Ni) is immersed in a 1 M nickel ion solution (Ni2+) and another electrode made of silver (Ag) is immersed in a 1 M silver ion solution (Ag+)? The reduction potential of Ni2+(aq) + 2e- → Ni(s) is -0.25 V, and the reduction potential of Ag+(aq) + e- → Ag(s) is +0.80 V.
message_2:
To find the standard potential of the cell, we need to determine which half-reaction will be the anode (oxidation) and which will be the cathode (reduction). The half-reaction with the higher reduction potential will be the cathode, and the other will be the anode.

In this case, the reduction potential of Ag+(aq) + e- → Ag(s) is higher (+0.80 V) than the reduction potential of Ni2+(aq) + 2e- → Ni(s) (-0.25 V). Therefore, the silver half-reaction will be the cathode, and the nickel half-reaction will be the anode.

Now we need to reverse the anode half-reaction to represent oxidation:

Ni(s) → Ni2+(aq) + 2e-

The oxidation potential of this reaction is the opposite of the reduction potential, so it is +0.25 V.

Finally, to find the standard potential of the cell, we add the oxidation potential of the anode to the reduction potential of the cathode:

E°cell = E°cathode + E°anode
E°cell = (+0.80 V) + (+0.25 V)
E°cell = +1.05 V

The standard potential of the cell is +1.05 V.
